thread.title: Financial advisers still push in-house products
thread.title_full: Financial advisers still push in-house products | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Karina Barrymore
title: Financial advisers still push in-house products
text:
FINANCIAL advisers are ­increasingly recommending retail superannuation funds and in-house products despite sweeping advice reforms, ­research shows.
There has been a big ­increase in advisers recommending retail super funds, ahead of better performing ­industry super funds, despite the best-interest rules.
According to a survey by Roy Morgan Research, 43 per cent of retail super fund clients came through a professional adviser last year, compared with 28 per cent the previous year. Financial advisers were responsible for just 7 per cent of new industry super fund ­clients last year.
The research, released on Thursday, also found “tied” financial advisers are increasingly recommending in-house products, despite reforms to ensure recommendations are only in the best interest of clients.
It found 77 per cent of clients who went to an adviser owned by one of the big financial groups were placed in an in-house super fund or product, compared with 76 per cent the previous year and 75 per cent in 2012.
Westpac and BT Group had the highest proportion of clients directed to in-house super funds at 82.4 per cent, up from 79 per cent the previous year. However, the Commonwealth Bank and CFS group advisers had the biggest increase at 71 per cent, up from 64 per cent.
“Despite the financial advice reforms, financial planners associated with the big financial groups are still more likely to recommend their own products,’’ Roy Morgan spokesman Norman Morris said on Thursday.
According to independent researchers Chant West and SuperRatings, industry funds have outperformed retail funds in almost every time period during the past 15 years.
 Advisers still push in-house products
